If you aren't using an SSL certificate f: If you aren't using an SSL certificate for your site that means you are losing a lot of potential traffic. We recommend getting an SSL certificate installed immediately.

Alternatively, you can create an empty i: Alternatively, you can create an empty index.php file and save it in every directory on your site. That's an approach that WordPress uses and it works well.

It's a great idea to try and hide the th: It's a great idea to try and hide the theme you have visible. From time to time vulnerabilities are found in themes and if your site is not updated in a timely fashion, outdated plugins and themes can be exploited.
Writing compelling titles is both a scie: Writing compelling titles is both a science and an art. There are automated tools that can analyze your title against known metrics for readability and click-worthiness. You also need to understand the psychology of your target audience.
Ensure your page's title includes your t: Ensure your page's title includes your target keywords, and design it to encourage users to click.

You can get an even greater boost in spe: You can get an even greater boost in speed with a content delivery network service. These services host a copy of your content on multiple servers spread out across the globe. A user's request is handled by the edge server that's closest to their physical location, so the content arrives incredibly fast.
If you want to continue to improve your: If you want to continue to improve your response time, the simplest and fastest fix is to use a caching plugin. Caching plugins keep a cached version of each page on your site. Instead of building the page from scratch, the server will send the cached copy.

Removing white space can also have an im: Removing white space can also have an impact on your HTML page's size. White space characters like carriage returns and tabs are ignored by the browser, but they make the markup easier for developers to read. So you should always strip them from your templates or themes before you use them in a production environment.
You can reduce CSS repetition with HTML: You can reduce CSS repetition with HTML class and ID attributes. Often the same rules will be repeated across many page elements, embedded in each tag's "style" attribute. You can extract them into a single "style" tag and use classes and ID's to target each element.
Sometimes inline CSS is a culprit. A lit: Sometimes inline CSS is a culprit. A little inline CSS can help your page render faster. Too much will bloat the HTML file and increase the page loading time.
In order to reduce page size, remove any: In order to reduce page size, remove any unnecessary tags from your markup. This includes developer comments, which are invisible to your users - search engines ignore the text in comments, too.

Alternatively, you can use a CMS plugin: Alternatively, you can use a CMS plugin to simplify the process - it's a more user-friendly option. WordPress has a host of caching plugins, and most of them give you options to control the caching headers.
If you use the Apache or NGINX web serve: If you use the Apache or NGINX web servers, you can edit the configuration files to set the "expires" header for all image files. For Apache, you can also use a ".htaccess" file to change the settings for each folder.

You should use HTTP redirections (301 pe: You should use HTTP redirections (301 permanant redirects) to pass PageRank from the "wrong" URLs to the standard (canonical) ones. That way, your content will still benefit from backlinks if someone makes a mistake and uses the wrong URL.
Decide whether you want your site's URLs: Decide whether you want your site's URLs to include a "www", or if you prefer a plain domain name. There are marketing pros and cons for each choice, but neither one is better or worse for SEO purposes - as long as you're consistent.
Both the www and non-www versions of the: Both the www and non-www versions of the URL are redirected to the same site.

Only ever use noindex meta tag or header: Only ever use noindex meta tag or header on pages you want to keep out of the reach of search engines!

If you've republished an article from an: If you've republished an article from another source (such as another site or a different section of your own site) then you need to pick which URL is the "correct" one and use that!
Every page on your site should have a <l: Every page on your site should have a <link> tag with a 'rel="canonical"' attribute. The link tag should go inside the page's head tag, and it should contain the page's "correct" URL.

Ideally, the links should be highly rele: Ideally, the links should be highly relevant to the subject you're writing about. It's impossible to cover every aspect of a subject on a single page, but your readers may be fascinated by some detail you barely touch on. If you link to a resource where they can learn more, they'll be grateful. What's more, you'll be rewarded with higher rankings!
Add links to external resources that are: Add links to external resources that are useful for your readers. Make sure you link to high-quality sites - Google penalizes pages that link to "spammy" sites (ones that break the Google webmaster guidelines).
The page has a correct number of interna: The page has a correct number of internal and external links.

Make sure every image has an alt tag, an: Make sure every image has an alt tag, and add useful descriptions to each image. Add your keywords or synonyms - but do it in a natural way.

Don't try to force keywords into sub-hea: Don't try to force keywords into sub-headings if they feel unnatural. It will send the wrong message to your readers, possibly driving them away.
It should be easy to include your main a: It should be easy to include your main and supporting keywords in the H2 tags - after all, these keywords describe your content! If it's hard to work the keywords into your subheadings, it could be a sign that the keywords aren't closely related to your content.
Also, try to include synonyms and releva: Also, try to include synonyms and relevant terminology in H2 tag text. Search engines are pretty smart - they know which words usually occur together in each niche.
Make sure you have a good balance of H2: Make sure you have a good balance of H2 tags to plain text in your content. Break the content down into logical sections, and use headings to introduce each new topic.

You should write as if your readers are: You should write as if your readers are selfish people with short attention spans (because that describes a large percentage of the world's population). Readers visit websites for selfish reasons - they're not there to make you happy.
A good headline stimulates reader intere: A good headline stimulates reader interest and offers a compelling reason to read your content. It promises a believable benefit.
Because your headline plays a large role: Because your headline plays a large role in reader engagement, it's worth spending extra time perfecting it. Many top copywriters spend hours getting their headlines just right - sometimes they spend longer on the headline than the rest of the article!
Ensure your most important keywords appe: Ensure your most important keywords appear in the H1 tag - don't force it, use them in a natural way that makes sense to human readers.
WordPress sites usually insert the page: WordPress sites usually insert the page or post title as an H1 tag (although custom themes can change this behavior).

For the best SEO results there should be: For the best SEO results there should be exactly one H1 tag on each page.
You need to use titles and descriptions: You need to use titles and descriptions that are attractive to users and contain your keywords. Use the keywords naturally - keyword stuffing is usually detected and will result in a lower ranking. What's more, it's pretty off-putting for potential readers, who are more likely to click on an appealing link.
